awd_titl_txt: Structural studies of DNA at replication fork junctions by 2D fluorescence spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
This award from the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) program supports work by Professor Andrew H. Marcus at the University of Oregon to determine the local conformations of DNA bases and backbones at replication fork junctions. These junctions are potential binding sites for proteins that manipulate genes. There are currently few techniques available that can provide detailed structural information about protein-DNA complexes, particularly those near DNA fork junctions. This project is developing methods that combine two fluorescence measurements, to specifically investigate DNA-protein structural dynamics at fork junctions. The methods are potentially of general use in understanding many processes of DNA biochemistry. In addition, such methods could potentially help to identify defects in the function of DNA replication, repair and cell cycle control complexes involved in human diseases. The tools are made readily available to the scientific community. The undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral students are benefitting from cross-disciplinary training and interactions with researchers that have a variety of scientific backgrounds.   

The research project uses two-dimensional fluorescence spectroscopy (2DFS) to investigate the local DNA base and backbone conformations and conformational dynamics at pre-selected sites within model DNA replication forks, and functional replication protein-DNA complexes. The experiments determine key structural end-states and DNA-protein binding recognition motifs important for the formation of replication complexes. The approaches employ DNA constructs containing two adjacently positioned fluorescent base analogue probes. In separate experiments, cyanine chromophores which absorb in a spectral region where DNA and proteins are transparent, are incorporated into the sugar-phosphate backbone. Coupling between the electronic states of the dimer probe residues produces signature spectral features that are used to infer local nucleic acid base or backbone conformation. The acquired information on dynamics is central to understanding mechanisms by which protein-DNA complexes assemble to carry out their specialized functions. A second goal of the project is to begin to develop single-molecule 2DFS to monitor local DNA conformational dynamics with sub-second time resolution.

This project is jointly funded by the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry and the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

por.por_cntn:
During the project period, the PI's group and collaborators performed novel spectroscopic experiments and developed theoretical and computational tools to study the local conformations of exciton-coupled fluorescent probes that are site-specifically positioned within model DNA fork constructs. Such probe-labeled DNA constructs are useful for mechanistic studies of protein-nucleic acid interactions, since they can report on the effects of protein assembly and binding at well-defined positions relative to the DNA fork junction. Specifically, a combination of absorbance spectroscopy, circular dichroism (CD), and two-dimensional fluorescence spectroscopy (2DFS, previously developed in the PI's lab) were implemented to determine the local conformations and conformational disorder of fluorescent probes placed at various positions within model DNA forks. In addition, important advancements were achieved for low flux signal detection that are needed to perform new single-molecule Fourier transform spectroscopic experiments on these same systems, and which will enable future studies to monitor local conformation fluctuations of protein-nucleic acid complexes in real time. 

Much of the completed work was carried out in collaboration with UO Prof. Peter H. von Hippel, who has extensive expertise in the biophysics of protein-nucleic acid interactions. Initial studies were performed on Cy3 dimer DNA constructs placed deep within the duplex region of DNA fork constructs to characterize the ability of the approach to report on the local conformation of the sugar-phosphate backbones of B-form DNA. Subsequent work showed how the local conformation of backbone segments is perturbed and becomes increasingly disordered at elevated temperatures. The approach was extended to examine the local conformations and conformational disorder of Cy3 dimer probes placed within the sugar-phosphate backbones near single-stranded (ss) – double-stranded (ds) DNA fork junctions. These studies revealed that the local conformation of backbone segments at the DNA fork junction can be very different than in the duplex region, and at certain positions adopt a left-handed (in contrast to the Watson-Crick right-handed) helicity. 2DFS experiments performed on Cy3 labeled DNA fork constructs showed that the well-ordered conformation of the sugar-phosphate backbones in the duplex region becomes abruptly disordered at temperatures significantly below the melting point (i.e., the pre-melting regime: 22 – 35 °C). In contrast, the local conformation of backbone segments near the DNA fork junction exhibited structural disorder very similar to that in ssDNA, which did not change as the temperature was increased through the melting point.

In parallel to the Cy3 studies described above, a procedure was established to determine the local base stacking conformations of a 6-MI base analogue probe (to Guanine) that was substituted within ssDNA and dsDNA constructs. The conformations were determined between the 6-MI probe and a site-selectively tethered acridine ligand, in which the acridine moiety inserted into the DNA duplex and displaced the base located directly opposite to the acridine attachment site.

Collaborative studies were pursued with theoretical groups at the UO and other institutions to examine how chemical structure of the probe-labeled nucleic acid systems contribute to spectroscopic signals. One collaboration with UO Prof. Marina Guenza examined the dependence of the distribution of DNA base stacking conformations on salt concentration, and how the various species of macrostates contribute to CD spectra. Another collaboration was carried out with Temple University Prof. Spiridoula Matsika and Penn State University, Brandywine Prof. Kurt Kistler to establish bench marks to the accuracy of electronic coupling models for the interpretation of absorbance, CD and 2DFS measurements of exciton-coupled Cy3 dimer-labeled DNA constructs. 

Research from the project produced two research commentaries and eight journal articles. Invited and contributed presentations at international meetings resulted in eight non-refereed published abstracts and three refereed published discussions. Two additional journal articles are in the final stages of preparation. During the project period, the PI presented > 20 invited lectures at international meetings, workshops, and university seminars. Two female graduate students, Loni Kringle and Huiying Ji, who received support from the project defended their PhD theses during the project period. 

The methods and research developed has created new possibilities to perform experiments in fields very different from the PI’s focus on protein-nucleic acid interactions. Research fields impacted include analytical chemistry, fluorescence imaging, single-molecule (sm) and nonlinear spectroscopy, applications of low-flux signal techniques to materials science and biophysical chemistry and quantum light spectroscopy.
